snippet: In an internal investigation, the company cited bureaucratic problems and the failure of individual employees to deal with a fatal ignition flaw, and said 15 had been dismissed.
abstract: Sweeping internal investigation of General Motors cites how employees across departments neglected for decade to repair faulty ignition switch and issue a recall, despite mountain of evidence that lives were at risk; defect has been linked to 13 deaths; company dismisses 15 employees, more than half at senior level; report by former United States Atty Anton R Valukas clears chief executive Mary T Barra of any wrongdoing.

byline.contributor: Rebecca R. Ruiz contributed reporting from New York.

lead_paragraph: In an internal investigation, the company cited bureaucratic problems and the failure of individual employees to deal with a fatal ignition flaw, and said 15 had been dismissed.

headline.main: G.M. Inquiry Cites Years of Neglect Over Fatal Defect
headline.print_headline: G.M. Inquiry Cites Years of Neglect Over Fatal Defect
